channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: China’s Birthrate Plunges to Lowest Level Since 1949
item.description: China’s population fell for a fourth straight year and its birthrate tumbled as policymakers failed to slow a demographic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Despite sweeping efforts to boost births, China’s population has shrunk and aged for a fourth straight year as deaths again outnumbered births.

item.title: Real Estate Crash Weighs on China’s Economic Growth
item.description: Falling apartment prices have erased the savings of millions of Chinese households, but exports lifted the economy to 5 percent growth last year.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: China is still grappling with a property market crash that began four years ago, after many years of overbuilding.

item.title: What Vietnam’s Communist Party Congress Hopes to Achieve
item.description: One of Asia’s most dynamic nations is weighing how to balance government control with raising per capita G.D.P. by about 70 percent in five years.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Tung Ngo
item.media:description: Signage for the 14th Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam outside the National Convention Center in Hanoi this month.

item.title: European Union Officials Lean Toward Negotiating, Not Retaliating, Over Trump Tariff Threat
item.description: European Union ambassadors held an emergency meeting on Sunday, and leaders from across the 27-nation bloc will meet in Brussels later this week.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: The flag of Greenland flying outside the Danish Parliament on Friday.

item.title: Danes Feel Betrayed and Bewildered by Trump Amid Greenland Threats
item.description: The American president’s vow to get Greenland, the semiautonomous Danish territory, has thrown the tiny, pro-American Nordic nation into crisis.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Bumiller and Hilary Swift
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gather at Råduspladsen, City Hall in Copenhagen on Saturday. People gathered in different cities in Denmark and Greenland to protest against US President Donald Trump’s designs to take over the Arctic island. The timing coinsided with a US delegations trip to Copenhagen.

item.title: In Minneapolis, a Pattern of Misconduct Toward Protesters
item.description: Legal and criminal justice experts said a ruling by a federal judge last week revealed conduct by immigration agents that evokes the civil rights era.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents hold down a protester outside the Whipple federal building in Minneapolis on Jan. 11.

item.title: Noem Denies Use of Chemical Agents in Minnesota Protests, Then Backtracks
item.description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, said officers had not used pepper spray and similar measures limited by a judge’s order, then was confronted with a video that showed chemical agents deployed.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:description: Kristi Noem, the secretary of homeland security, at the White House last week.

item.title: Springsteen Denounces ICE Deployments and Renee Good’s Killing
item.description: In a surprise appearance in New Jersey, the musician dedicated his song “The Promised Land” to Ms. Good, who was killed by an ICE agent in Minneapolis this month.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Bruce Springsteen performing in Los Angeles in October.

item.title: One State, Two Very Different Views of Minneapolis
item.description: Pull up a stool at Ye Old Pickle Factory and listen to a story about America’s urban-rural divide.
item.dc:creator: Sheila M. Eldred, Elizabeth A. Stawicki, Ann Hinga Klein, Kurt Streeter and Jamie Kelter Davis
item.media:description: Outside of the Twin Cities area, at places like Ye Old Pickle Factory in Nisswa, Minn., support for Immigration and Customs Enforcement is widespread.

item.title: White House Warns CBS: Air Trump Interview in Full, or ‘We’ll Sue’
item.description: In previously unreported remarks, the White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told CBS News that Mr. Trump would “sue” the news outlet if it did not air an interview unedited.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:description: Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, at a briefing at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: One Month Later, CBS Airs Postponed ‘60 Minutes’ Report With Few Changes
item.description: A 13-minute segment about Venezuelan men deported by the Trump administration had been pulled at the last minute by CBS News’s editor in chief, Bari Weiss.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The report featured the stories of Venezuelan men deported by the Trump administration to a prison in El Salvador.

item.title: San Francisco Mourns Its Beloved Alligator, Claude
item.description: The 30-year-old albino resident of the California Academy of Sciences died last month. On Sunday, thousands paid tribute.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight and Poppy Lynch
item.media:description: A nearly life-size sourdough loaf depicting Claude, the albino alligator who died last month, was created by Boudin Bakery, in San Francisco.

item.title: What We Know About the Deadly High-Speed Train Crash in Spain
item.description: The collision, caused by the derailment of one of the trains, was the deadliest in Spain since at least 2013.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim
item.media:description: A person affected by a deadly train derailment is transferred for treatment to the Caseta Municipal in Adamuz, Spain, on Sunday.

item.title: As Davos Convenes, Deference to Trump Has Replaced Everything
item.description: The traditional rhetoric of the World Economic Forum centered on global integration, climate change and international cooperation. Not anymore.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:description: Attendees at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last year.

item.title: Can Davos Help Protect the Planet?
item.description: The World Economic Forum, which takes place in Switzerland, aims to meet at least some of the goals its leaders set for the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora
item.media:description: The town of Davos, Switzerland, site of the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting. Over the years, the event’s organizers have been working to reduce the environmental impact of the meeting.

item.title: Josh Shapiro Writes That Harris Team Asked if He Had Ever Been an Israeli Agent
item.description: In his new memoir, the Pennsylvania governor suggests that when Kamala Harris’s team vetted him to be her running mate, aides focused on Israel to an extent he found offensive.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new memoir by Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania goes into detail about his experience being vetted to be former Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate in 2024.

item.title: Buttigieg, Booker Lead Midterm Democratic Health Care Push
item.description: The potential 2028 presidential candidates showcased a Democratic midterm strategy that would assail G.O.P. votes in favor of cutting Medicaid and allowing health care subsidies to expire.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning and Allison Braden
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: Pete Buttigieg argued that pressure from Wisconsinites had led their Republican congressional representative to vote in support of extending enhanced health care subsidies.

item.title: Trump Backs a Potential Primary Challenger to Bill Cassidy, a G.O.P. Senator
item.description: The president urged Representative Julia Letlow of Louisiana to run against Mr. Cassidy, in a move that is likely to further complicate his relationship with Senate Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Bill Cassidy, Republican of Louisiana, has sometimes criticized President Trump and voted to convict him in his second impeachment trial.

item.title: With Her First Novel, Jennette McCurdy Wants to See You Squirm
item.description: The author of the memoir “I’m Glad My Mom Died” hopes her debut novel, about a teen’s sexual relationship with her teacher, will make readers uncomfortable.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Anger’s a really useful place to write from,” says Jennette McCurdy about “Half His Age,” her first novel.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Half His Age,’ by Jennette McCurdy
item.description: Jennette McCurdy follows “I’m Glad My Mom Died” with “Half His Age,” a debut novel that confirms her gift as a chronicler of disaffected girlhood.
item.dc:creator: Brittany Newell
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennette McCurdy in 2020, just before the release of her memoir, “I’m Glad My Mom Died.”

item.title: The Man Delivering FedEx Into the Age of Drones, Robots and A.I.
item.description: Raj Subramaniam took over three years ago from FedEx’s founder, who ran the company for nearly 50 years. Since then, technology, tariffs and other disruptions have “fundamentally shifted” patterns of global trade.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Whitten Sabbatini for The New York Times
item.media:description: FedEx, which handles more than 17 million packages per day, is the “heartbeat of the industrial economy,” Mr. Subramaniam said.

item.title: Why Are New Zealanders Moving to Australia? More Money, Better Vibes.
item.description: More than 1 percent of New Zealand’s population left over the year ending in October. Many of the migrants were chasing salaries and opportunities in neighboring Australia.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Tatsiana Chypsanava
item.media:description: Travelers at Wellington International Airport, in New Zealand last month.

item.title: How a Play Skewering Modern Russia Evaded a Crackdown to Become a Hit
item.description: Everyone expected “The Kholops,” a drama exploring oppression, to be shut down soon after it opened in St. Petersburg. Instead, it is two years into a sold-out run.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: How to Prevent Aging Parents and Relatives from Making Financial Mistakes
item.description: Getting family members to listen to you when you think they are headed down a dangerous financial path can be difficult. But there are preventive steps you can take.
item.dc:creator: Paulette Perhach
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2024, Rianka Dorsainvil’s mother came to her with a check that looked legitimate. It turned out to be part of a common check fraud scam.

item.title: I’m the Secretary General of the Council of Europe. This Is Something I Thought I’d Never Have to Write.
item.description: International law is either universal or meaningless. Greenland will show which one we choose.
item.dc:creator: Alain Berset
item.media:description: The U.S. consulate in Nuuk, Greenland.

item.title: Dear Trump, Buying Greenland Is a Bad Idea
item.description: Trump wants Greenland? Its previous colonizer has some thoughts.
item.dc:creator: Huxi Bach, Casper Kofod, Francesca Trianni and James Robinson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Winter Storm Brings Snow and Cold Temps as Far South as Florida and Georgia
item.description: Snow fell as far south as Florida and Georgia on Sunday but mostly melted by the afternoon. The same storm system brought snow to the Northeast, with a second round expected Sunday night.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff
item.media:credit: John Blackie/Pensacola News Journal, via USA Today Network
item.media:description: Snow falling early on Sunday morning at a Hyundai dealership in Pensacola, Fla. Snow was also falling in parts of Georgia.

item.title: Guatemala Declares State of Emergency to Address Gang Violence
item.description: The country has seen a surge of unrest in recent days, including uprisings at prisons and the killing of police officers, which the authorities have blamed on gangs.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Guatemalan riot police officers guard the entrance to the men’s Preventive Detention Center in Guatemala City on Sunday.

item.title: Ralph Towner, Eclectic Guitarist With the Ensemble Oregon, Dies at 85
item.description: A composer and pianist as well, he was a prolific recording artist who integrated jazz, classical and world music traditions in a career that spanned seven decades.
item.dc:creator: Hank Shteamer
item.media:description: Mr. Towner in about 1976. He took up the guitar after seeing a fellow student playing a Bach piece on it. He later moved to Vienna, where he studied with a renowned Austrian guitarist and teacher.

item.title: Prince Harry’s Court Case Against Daily Mail Publisher: What to Know
item.description: A trial is set to begin on Monday in Harry’s case accusing Associated Newspapers of phone hacking and other unlawful activities. Other claimants include Elton John and Liz Hurley.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Prince Harry leaving the High Court in London after giving evidence. He has pursued several legal battles aimed at holding Britain’s tabloids to account over unlawful news gathering.
